radiographic_examinations.procedure_name: Laser Doppler measurement of retinal blood circulation
radiographic_examinations.findings: Decreased venous blood flow in the left eye with enlarged diameters of the left superotemporal and inferotemporal veins. Average centerline blood velocity in the superotemporal vein was 8.7 mm/second, 75% below normal.
radiographic_examinations.changes_over_time: During the hospitalization, the patient showed improvement in visual symptoms. One week after discharge, worsened visual symptoms were noted, with increased tortuosity and dot hemorrhages in the left fundus. A subsequent retinal blood circulation study showed further decrease in venous blood velocity. After 4 months of warfarin treatment, the retinal blood circulation study indicated reduction of retinal venous diameters toward normal caliber. By 7 months after initial presentation, visual acuity remained 20/20 in both eyes, and retinal veins were no longer tortuous; hemorrhages had resolved.

radiographic_examinations.findings: Unremarkable in the right eye; significant decrease in venous return from the superotemporal and superonasal veins in the left eye.
radiographic_examinations.changes_over_time: Initially showed normal findings, later indicated significant slowing of venous return from the affected veins without leakage in the late phase.
